A 'biotransducer' converts the biochemical signal to an electronic signal. It
gives the biosensor selectivity and specificity. Typically biotransducers
consist of two main parts; a bio-recognition layer and a physico-transducer. The
bio-recognition layer typically contain an enzyme or another binding protein
such as antibody. By using oligonucleotide sequences, sub-cellular fragments
such as organelles (e.g. mitochondria) and receptor carrying fragments (e.g.
cell wall), single whole cells, small numbers of cells on synthetic scaffolds,
or thin slices of animal or plant tissues, the bio-recognition layer can also be
created. A physico-transducer typically contacts with the recognition layer. A
physic-chemical change that produced by the recognition layer due to the
analyte, is measured by the
transducer. http://www.clemson.edu/c3b/biosensorsPrimer.html

Bio transducers vary from electrochemical, optical, piezoelectric and FET based.
